verses.text: On the third day, Esther put on her royal garments and stood in the inner court of the king’s palace, opposite the king’s hall. The king was seated on his royal throne inside the hall, facing the entrance.
verses.comment: Esther's preparation and timing here echoes holy customs of ceremonial preparation (see Exodus 28:40). Her courageous act mirrors intercession, drawing on imagery of royal mediation seen in the Psalms. The 'third day' can be seen as a symbolic foreshadowing of victory and resurrection, which carries deeper implications in salvation history.

verses.text: When the king saw Queen Esther standing in the court, she found favor in his sight. The king held out to Esther the golden scepter that was in his hand. So Esther approached and touched the tip of the scepter.
verses.comment: Esther's approach and the king's gesture signify both mercy and acceptance, reminiscent of the favor shown to Joseph (Genesis 41:39-41). The touching of the scepter symbolizes both obedience and admission into the royal presence, connecting to biblical concepts of drawing near to God.

verses.text: Then the king asked her, "What is it, Queen Esther? What do you wish? Even if it is half of the kingdom, it will be granted to you."
verses.comment: The king's extravagant offer echoes other royal promises (1 Kings 2:6; Matthew 14:7), representing a trust and generosity extended to those closest to the throne. This prefigures the abundant grace bestowed through intercession.

verses.text: Esther answered, "If it pleases the king, let the king and Haman come today to the banquet I have prepared for him."
verses.comment: Esther invites the king and his adviser to a banquet, presenting hospitality similar to divine feasts (Psalm 23:5). The meal setting hints at spiritual nourishment and foreshadows later biblical banquets associated with the kingdom.

verses.text: Then the king said, "Bring Haman quickly, so that we may do what Esther has asked." So the king and Haman went to the banquet that Esther prepared.
verses.comment: The hasty preparation and obedience to Esther’s invitation parallels Abraham’s hospitality (Genesis 18:6), emphasizing the importance of responding swiftly to sacred moments.

verses.text: While they drank wine, the king asked Esther, "What is your petition? It shall be granted to you. What is your request? Even up to half the kingdom, it will be done."
verses.comment: The sharing of wine aligns with biblical imagery of joy and covenant (Psalm 104:15). The king’s repeated offer shows his willingness to answer petitions, a reminder of God’s generosity to those who ask in faith (Luke 11:9-13).

verses.text: Esther replied, "My petition and my request is this:
verses.comment: Esther’s humility and respect as she presents her case is reminiscent of the reverence shown in prayerful petition (Psalm 21:2). It reflects faithful reliance on wise mediation in approaching authority.

verses.text: "If I have found favor in the sight of the king, and if it pleases the king to grant my petition and fulfill my request, let the king and Haman come tomorrow to the banquet that I will prepare for them. Then I will do as the king has said."
verses.comment: Esther employs patience and wisdom, inviting the king to a second banquet. This two-step approach signifies discernment and devotion, at times necessary to convey grave matters. The repeated inviting hints at persistent prayer (Matthew 7:7-8) and the role of grace in granting favor.

verses.text: Haman went out that day joyful and with a glad heart. But when Haman saw Mordecai at the king’s gate, and Mordecai neither rose nor trembled before him, Haman was filled with fury against Mordecai.
verses.comment: Haman’s pride contrasts sharply with Mordecai’s steadfastness; Haman’s anger mirrors the reactions of the wicked against the righteous (Psalm 112:10, Proverbs 29:27). This foreshadows the enduring tension between evil and those who remain faithful.

verses.text: Nevertheless, Haman restrained himself and went to his house. There he called for his friends and his wife Zeresh.
verses.comment: Haman’s restraint is temporary and fueled by pride. His preference for seeking counsel from family and friends reflects the biblical theme of seeking advice, but in a spirit of self-interest (Proverbs 13:10).

verses.text: Then Haman recounted to them the glory of his riches, the number of his sons, and how the king had promoted him above the officials and servants of the king.
verses.comment: Haman’s boasting of wealth, family, and high status points to the emptiness of earthly glory without humility (Psalm 49:16-17, Luke 12:15). It contrasts with biblical teaching about true riches found in service and self-sacrifice.

verses.text: Moreover, Haman added, "Queen Esther invited no one but me to come with the king to the banquet she prepared, and tomorrow I am also invited by her together with the king."
verses.comment: Haman dwells on his exclusivity, revealing self-centered pride. The emphasis on personal invitation juxtaposes humility before God and the dangers of arrogance (Psalm 36:2).

verses.text: Yet all this avails me nothing, so long as I see Mordecai the Jew sitting at the king’s gate."
verses.comment: Haman’s fixation on Mordecai’s presence negates all his joys, picturing the way envy and pride spoil blessings—contrasted with rewards given to the persecuted who remain steadfast in faith (Psalm 73:3, Matthew 5:10-12).

verses.text: Then Zeresh his wife and all his friends said to him, "Let a gallows fifty cubits high be made, and in the morning, ask the king to have Mordecai hanged on it. Then go joyfully with the king to the banquet." This suggestion pleased Haman; so he ordered the gallows to be made.
verses.comment: The plot against Mordecai displays premeditated evil, yet echoes warnings about the fate of those who dig pits for the righteous (Proverbs 26:27). Spiritually, this scene calls to mind persecution of God's people and eventual vindication, an anticipation of the victory of righteousness over evil.
